thread.title: Woman's vote for Brexit swayed by shape of bananas
thread.title_full: Woman's vote for Brexit swayed by shape of bananas

title: Woman's vote for Brexit swayed by shape of bananas
text:
Woman's vote for Brexit swayed by shape of bananas By 
A woman in the UK has been ridiculed on social media after she claimed on a live TV show that the shape of bananas made her vote for Brexit. 
The woman was an audience member on the weekly BBC news panel programme Question Time on Thursday. 
After the panel of politicians and commentators discussed Britain triggering its withdrawl from the UK, host David Dimbleby took comments from audience members. 
The woman declared that seeing a straight banana in a shop made her change her vote in last June’s referendum on EU membership from the Remain camp to the Leave option. 
She explained to Dimbleby and a national TV audience of about 2.7 million viewers how she was influence by the “silly” EU regulations on the fruit’s shape. 
“I was voting remain, and at the very last minute I changed my decision and I went to leave,” she said. 
“And the reason is because I go to a supermarket, and a banana is straight. I’m just sick of the silly rules that come out of Europe.” 
Dimbleby then asked, jokingly: "Have the bananas changed?" 
She replied: “If you go to Aldi they’re a bit bent.” 
Social media quickly erupted with comments about the audience member’s comments. 
One said: “Much respect to Banana woman on #questiontime for not being afraid to sound like the biggest clown this week, despite strong competition.” 
“Jesus Christ. Shape of a banana changed your vote. This is the level of reasoning we are dealing with?” added another, while another said: “Does she realise that she said that out loud and on national television!” 
The European Parliament Information Office to the UK states that bendy bananas are not banned by the EU. 
Its website states: ”Straight and bendy [bananas] are not banned by the EU. Commission Regulation 2257/94 identifies certain restrictions for fruits that producers have to conform to in order to sell their produce within the EU. 
“The regulation states that bananas must be ‘free from malformation or abnormal curvature’.”
